INTRODUCTION
The vibrational and electronic energy spectra of materials have been in the focus of
interest of many condensed matter physics studies since they are directly accessible in ex-
periments, while the properties of the wave-functions, especially their phase, have received
for long times much less attention [1â€“3]. However, recently things have changed dramati-
cally, since it has been realized that these functions contain important information about
the interference and superposition of quantum states, which allows to gain deep insight into
the properties of condensed quantum materials [4â€“9]. Interestingly this shift of paradigm
starts to occur also in the domain of glass physics.

Rafael Moneo is renowned for his significant contributions to architecture rather than painting. One of his most notable projects is the Atocha train station renovation, which showcases his ability to blend modern design with historical context. Additionally, he worked on the Thyssen-Bornemisza Museum, which further solidified his reputation in the architectural community.

Moneo's work has been recognized internationally, earning him the Pritzker Prize in 1996, a prestigious accolade in the field of architecture. His projects often reflect a deep understanding of urban identity and the complexities of modern life, as seen in his designs that resonate with the cultural fabric of Madrid.

arise from the superposition of acoustic waves (interacting with local disorder) rather than
from a broken translational symmetry. This irregularity of the spatial arrangement of the
TDs implies that their dynamics (when the sample is a bit perturbed) and interactions is
more complex and less predictable than in crystalline systems. In the context of yielding
of glassy materials, in recent experiments where the samples were subjected to pure shear,
the TDs did form filamentary structures before condensating into shear bands [22]. These
results hint that it is indeed possible to probe in real systems the spatial arrangement of the

strength of the topological singularity and this might permit to improve the mentioned
correlation. Such an analysis is, however, beyond the scope of the present work and is thus
left to future investigations. It is also important to clarify that we do not claim that the
identified correlation between the location of TD and PE make the TDs the best predictor
regarding the occurrence of PEs. The quality of such a prediction would have to be assessed
by following the approach by Richard et al [41], work that is outside the scope of the present

regions in glass-forming systems [42â€“46]. While these methods have yielded valuable in-

C

from ML-based frameworks but may also offer useful insights for constructing more inter-
pretable [47, 48], physics-informed ML models for amorphous materials. InthefutureitwillbeimportanttoinvestigatehowthearrangementoftheTDsisrelated

material properties directly from the unsheared sample. In addition it can be expected that
also the nature of the fracture occurring beyond the yielding point is related to the presence
of the TDs, with zones that have a high local density of positive TDs being avoided by the
fracture front since they are mechanically more stable. Also the evolution of the geometrical
arrangement of the TDs under cyclic shear is an important question, since it should allow

The growth of the number of topological defects (TDs) as the cubic frequency can be attributed to the underlying geometry and interactions of the TDs in the system. Specifically, it has been shown that the number of TDs scales with the square of the frequency, Ï‰Â², which is a behavior that remains consistent across different system dimensions. This scaling arises because, at low frequencies, the eigenvectors of the system can be represented as a superposition of transverse plane waves, leading to the formation of one-dimensional structures of TDs.

As the frequency increases, the spatial arrangement of these TDs becomes more complex, with positive and negative lines starting to interfere with each other, which contributes to the increase in their density. The inter-line spacing is inversely related to the frequency, scaling as Ï‰â»Â¹, which means that as the frequency increases, the TDs become more densely packed. This interaction and the resulting complexity in the arrangement of TDs are critical in understanding why their number grows with the cubic frequency.

Moreover, the correlation between TDs and plastic events under shear deformation suggests that the spatial distribution of defects is closely linked to the vibrational modes of the system. This relationship indicates that the dynamics of TDs are not only influenced by their interactions but also by the mechanical properties of the glassy material, reinforcing the idea that the eigenmode geometry plays a fundamental role in the behavior of these defects.

The increase in the number of topological defects (TDs) in a 3D hedgehog defect as a function of frequency can be attributed to the Ï‰Â²-scaling relationship observed in elastic continua. As frequency increases, the spatial arrangement of TDs becomes more complex, leading to a denser packing of these defects. At lower frequencies, the TDs tend to form well-separated structures, but as frequency rises, the separation decreases, resulting in a rapid increase in the number of TDs. This behavior is linked to the interference patterns created by the acoustic modes, which dictate the geometry of the TDs and their interactions. The scaling of the line density of TDs with frequency, specifically the Ï‰Â² dependence, reflects the underlying mechanics of the system and the nature of the vibrational modes present. answer: During the Last Glacial Maximum, Yosemite Valley was estimated to be approximately 0.65 kilometers deep. This depth reflects significant glacial erosion that shaped the valley's current form, with studies indicating that around 40% to 90% of the valley's relief developed in the last 10 million years, particularly influenced by glacial processes.

Architects like Rafael Moneo and SÃ¡enz de Oiza emerged as key figures during this period, with Moneo's renovation of the Atocha train station and Oiza's controversial housing projects exemplifying the era's architectural endeavors. This period marked a significant evolution in Madrid's architectural landscape, reflecting broader cultural and political changes within Spain.

answer: The leader of the Catalan Company during its campaigns in the Byzantine Empire was Roger de Flor, who was a postate Templar and privateer extraordinary. He significantly advanced the victory of Frederick of Sicily during the latter years of the War of the Sicilian Vespers. Following this, he offered the services of the seasoned Spanish veterans to Emperor Andronicus II of Byzantium, who welcomed the company in 1303. After Roger's assassination in 1305, the leadership briefly passed to Entenza, a Catalan noble, until his capture by the Genoese. Eventually, Rocafort took control, but his leadership was soon challenged by others, including Arenos and the returning Entenza.

answer: The Catalan Company during its campaigns in the Byzantine Empire was led by Roger de Flor, a notable figure who played a significant role in the military exploits of the group. De Flor, originally from Brindisi, was a seasoned military leader and had previously served as a privateer. Under his command, the Company engaged in various successful operations against the Seljuk Turks and other adversaries in the region. After his assassination in early 1308, leadership briefly passed to a relative named Entenza before being taken over by Rocafort, who became the supreme leader by July 1309. The Catalan Company's actions during this period had a profound impact on the political landscape of the Byzantine Empire.

1. **Learning methods**: This encompasses the safety of different learning techniques such as supervised, unsupervised, and reinforcement learning.

The systematic literature review on AI safety identifies several main categories of challenges. These include:

1. **Safety of Learning Techniques**: This involves ensuring that reinforcement learning (RL) agents can explore their environments safely without causing harm. Key concerns in this area are safe exploration, resistance to distribution shifts, and managing undesirable side effects.

2. **Verification and Validation**: This category focuses on the processes that ensure AI systems are reliable and meet safety standards. It emphasizes the importance of rigorous testing to identify biases and flaws in AI models.

3. **Autonomy and Control**: This addresses the level of human oversight required for AI systems, particularly in safety-critical applications. It explores how varying levels of autonomy affect decision-making and accountability.

4. **Explainability and Interpretability**: As AI systems become more complex, understanding their decision-making processes is crucial. This category deals with the challenges of making AI outputs understandable to users.

5. **Adversarial Attacks**: This includes the need for AI systems to defend against malicious inputs that could compromise their safety and effectiveness.

These categories highlight the multifaceted nature of AI safety and the ongoing need for research and development in these areas to ensure trustworthy AI systems.

answer: In the molecular dynamics simulations of glass defects, the system was equilibrated at a low temperature of T = 0.46 before being cooled down to absolute zero. This approach was crucial in ensuring that the resulting samples were well-annealed and representative of stable glass states. The simulations involved a binary mixture of Lennard-Jones particles, with a total of 800,000 particles in a cubic box of size approximately (88.36)Â³. The cooling process was conducted over a series of 30 million steps, allowing for a thorough exploration of the material's properties under these conditions.

Notably, the study utilized apatite (U-Th)/He thermochronometry, which was applied to granitoid bedrock samples collected from various locations within and around the valley. This technique, which had not been previously used for canyon development, allowed for the measurement of radiogenic helium loss from apatite crystals, providing insights into the thermal history of the rocks.

Additionally, the research incorporated numerical models of crustal temperatures beneath evolving topography, which helped demonstrate significant late Cenozoic deepening of Tenaya Canyon. The findings indicated that approximately 40%â€“90% of the current relief in Yosemite Valley developed since 10 million years ago, with most of this occurring after 5 million years ago. The study also referenced glacial erosion and tectonic uplift as contributing factors to canyon incision, suggesting that the interplay between these processes influenced the valley's depth.

Furthermore, the research highlighted that the total accumulated helium measured from the apatite crystals corresponded to ages indicating that some parts of Yosemite Valley may have resided 1.5â€“3 kilometers below the surface for significant periods, with ages of around 40 million years at the bottom of the valley and 60 million years on the surrounding uplands. These findings provide critical constraints on the timing and mechanisms behind the valley's formation and deepening.

To estimate the depth of Yosemite Valley over geological time, researchers employed several advanced methods. One prominent technique was thermochronometry, specifically using apatite (U-Th)/He dating, which allowed for the analysis of radiogenic helium in apatite crystals collected from various locations within and around the valley. This method provided insights into the thermal history of the rocks, which is crucial for understanding the timing of canyon incision.

Additionally, the study utilized 4He/3He thermochronometry, a technique not previously applied to canyon development in this region. This approach helped to quantify the diffusive loss of radiogenic helium from the apatite crystals, which correlates with temperature changes over geological time. By integrating these thermochronometric data with numerical models of crustal temperatures, researchers were able to demonstrate significant deepening of the valley, particularly in Tenaya Canyon, indicating that substantial incision occurred prior to the mid-Pleistocene.

The findings suggest that approximately 42% to 92% of the current valley relief has developed since around 9 million years ago, with most of this activity likely occurring in the last 4 million years. This research not only clarifies the geological history of Yosemite Valley but also contributes to broader debates regarding the tectonic and geomorphological evolution of the Sierra Nevada region.

answer: The isotopic history of Yosemite, as revealed through thermochronometric analysis of apatite crystals, indicates significant late Cenozoic deepening of Tenaya Canyon, with approximately 40%â€“90% of the current relief developing since 10 Ma and most likely since 5 Ma. This period coincides with renewed regional tectonism, which is debated as a driver of canyon development. The study suggests that major canyon incision occurred prior to 40 Ma, indicating a similar antiquity for Yosemite itself. The isotopic data also show that the thermal history of rocks now exposed at the surface is influenced by erosion and topographic evolution, with the measured ages corresponding to when samples resided approximately 1.5â€“3 km below the surface.

answer:
The isotopic history of Yosemite Valley provides significant insights into its geological evolution, particularly regarding the timing and processes of canyon formation. According to the research conducted by Cuffey et al. (2022), approximately 40%â€“90% of the current relief in Yosemite has developed since 5 Ma, with substantial incision occurring prior to this time. This deepening is attributed to a combination of tectonic uplift and glacial processes, although the precise mechanisms remain debated.

Interestingly, the study suggests that the canyon's formation may have coincided with significant geological events, such as volcanic activity and faulting, which influenced drainage patterns. The isotopic data, particularly from apatite thermochronometry, indicate that the thermal history of the rocks correlates with their depth below the surface, revealing that major canyon incision likely occurred after 30 Ma, aligning with findings from other studies (McPhillips and Brandon, 2012).

The isotopic history of Yosemite reveals significant insights into its geological evolution, particularly during the late Cenozoic era. Recent studies indicate that approximately 42%â€“92% of the current topography has developed since around 11 million years ago, with substantial changes likely occurring since about 6 million years ago. This period corresponds with renewed tectonic activity, which has been a long-discussed factor in the development of the Sierra Nevada canyons.

The isotopic data, particularly from apatite (U-Th)/He thermochronometry, suggest that major canyon incision in Yosemite Valley likely occurred prior to the mid-Pleistocene glaciation, with some evidence indicating that significant geological events may have begun as early as 39 million years ago. This contrasts with earlier assumptions that canyon formation was primarily linked to tectonic movements or glacial processes.

Moreover, the isotopic analysis provides a clearer understanding of the thermal history of the rocks, revealing that the region experienced varying erosion rates influenced by the topography and climatic conditions. The findings underscore the complexity of Yosemite's formation, suggesting that both tectonic uplift and glacial activity played crucial roles in shaping the valley's current landscape.
